qas.question: What is one thing the cell must do once DNA replication is compete?

answers.text: physically separate the two copies of the genome

qas.question: What is another thing the cell must do once DNA replication is complete?

answers.text: divide into two distinct membrane-bound cells

qas.question: In binary fission, what shape is each genome?
In binary fission. when does each genome separate into daughter cells?

answers.text: as the membrane invaginates to split the cytoplasm

qas.question: Compared to the rates of cell division in eukaryotes, with what speed does binary fission occur?

context: After DNA replication is complete, the cell must <a0_0>physically separate the two copies of the genome<a0_0/> and <a1_0>divide into two distinct membrane-bound cells<a1_0/>.:18.2 In prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea) this usually occurs via a relatively simple process called binary fission, in which each <a2_0>circular<a2_0/> genome attaches to the cell membrane and is separated into the daughter cells <a3_0>as the membrane invaginates to split the cytoplasm<a3_0/> into two membrane-bound portions. Binary fission is <a4_0>extremely fast<a4_0/> compared to the rates of cell division in eukaryotes. Eukaryotic cell division is a more complex process known as the cell cycle; DNA replication occurs during a phase of this cycle known as S phase, whereas the process of segregating chromosomes and splitting the cytoplasm occurs during M phase.:18.1
